objectives: Express friendship and share personal news clearly

sections.text: An informal letter is a personal letter you write to someone you know well, like a friend, family member, or close relative. It is different from a formal letter because it has a friendly, relaxed, and casual tone. You can use simple and everyday language, just like you talk to your friend. There are no strict rules for writing it. You can share news, feelings, or just stay in touch.

sections.text: Here is a complete look at how an informal letter is put together. Each part has its own place.

table.title: Informal Letter Format
rows: Your full address (e.g., House No., Village, District, State, Pin Code)
The date you are writing the letter (e.g., July 18, 2025)
Friendly greeting (e.g., Dear [Friend's Name], Hi [Friend's Name],)
Below the date, usually on a new line
Ask about their well-being, mention reason for writing, or react to their last letter.
Share your news, thoughts, feelings, ask questions. (2-3 paragraphs usually)
Wrap up your thoughts, express desire to meet or hear back.
Friendly closing (e.g., With love, Best wishes, Take care,)
Below the body, right side or center

topics.title: Tone and Language in Informal Letters

sections.text: Here is an example of an informal letter from a student in a rural area to their friend. Notice the friendly language and personal details.
usage_examples:
Village Post Office,
Near Banyan Tree,
Rampur - 456789,
Bihar.

July 18, 2025

Dear Rahul,

How are you? I hope this letter finds you and your family well. It feels like ages since we last met, and I wanted to tell you about whatâ€™s happening here in our village.

Life here is good. The monsoon rains have been good this year, and our paddy fields are looking green and beautiful. Father says the harvest will be great. Yesterday, we had a small village fair. It was fun! There were many stalls with sweets and toys, and a puppet show. I bought a small flute for my younger sister. She was so happy.

I also helped my mother with the farming work for a few days. It was hard work under the hot sun, but it felt good to help. I also saw a new type of bird near the river. It had blue feathers and sang a beautiful song. I wish you were here to see it.

What about you? How is your new school in the city? Are you making new friends? I hope you are enjoying your studies. Did you visit your grandparents this summer? Do write back and tell me everything.

Well, thatâ€™s all for now. I hope to see you during the Diwali holidays. Give my regards to your parents.

With love,

Sunil

subtopics.title: Sample Letter 2: Inviting to Village for Festival

sections.text: This sample letter invites a friend to the village for a festival. It uses a warm tone and shares details about the event.
usage_examples:
House No. 12,
Gandhi Nagar,
Shahpur - 789012,
Uttar Pradesh.

July 18, 2025

Dear Priya,

Hope you are doing well! I'm so excited to tell you about the upcoming Village Harvest Festival next month. You remember how much fun we had last year, right? I really hope you can come this time too.

The festival starts on August 15th and will last for three days. There will be traditional dances, folk songs, and delicious food stalls with local dishes. This year, they are also planning a bullock cart race! It will be very exciting. My grandmother is making her special laddus, and you know how much you love them.

My parents would be very happy if you could stay with us. We can visit the temple, swim in the clean river, and play hide-and-seek in the fields, just like old times. All our old friends from school will also be here. It would be wonderful to see everyone together.

Please try your best to come. Let me know when you can arrive so I can tell my parents. I am eagerly waiting for your reply.

Lots of love,

Anjali

subtopics.title: Practice Activity: Write a Letter to a Friend

sections.text:
Now, it's your turn to write an informal letter to your friend. Choose one of the ideas below, or write about your own recent experiences. Remember to follow the format and use friendly language.

Things to include:
1.  Your Address and Date.
2.  A friendly Greeting (e.g., Dear [Friend's Name],).
3.  An Introduction (ask how they are, mention why you are writing).
4.  Main Content (share your news, thoughts, or feelings, ask questions).
5.  A friendly Closing (e.g., With love, Take care,).
6.  Your First Name as a Signature.
